IN the First Series of Studia Biblz‘ea, p. 144 foll„ Bishop John Wordsworth adduces the following arguments to show that our Epistle was probably written in Aramaic :1—(1') This was the language usually spoken by our Lord. (2) It was used by St. Paul in his address to the mob of Jerusalem. (3) We are told by Papias that the Gospel of St. Matthew was originally written in Hebrew (i.e. Aramaic) and interpreted by each as he was able.2 (4) Papias also states that St. Mark acted as interpreter to St. Peter, and Glaucias, claimed by the Gnostics as the teacher of Basilides, is named as another interpreter of the same Apostle.3 Jerome takes it for granted that the Epistles of St. Peter were not originally written in Greek, and thinks that the difference between them was due to the employment of different men as interpreters.4 (5) Some of the Fathers supposed the Epistle to the Hebrews to have been written in Hebrew.⁵ Josephus wrote his book on the Wars of the Jews in ‘his national language ' and
